name: Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT)
summary: A structured, evidence-based cognitive-behavioral therapy developed to help individuals recover from post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and related conditions by addressing maladaptive trauma-related thoughts.
description: Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) is a manualized, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral treatment primarily used for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). It was originally developed for survivors of sexual assault but has since been widely applied to military veterans, first responders, and other trauma survivors. CPT helps individuals identify and challenge maladaptive trauma-related beliefs (e.g., about safety, trust, power, control, self-worth, and intimacy). By restructuring these cognitions, CPT reduces symptoms of re-experiencing, avoidance, negative alterations in cognition and mood, and hyperarousal. CPT is typically delivered in 12 structured sessions and can be conducted individually or in group settings.

clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe and well-tolerated; temporary symptom exacerbation is possible when processing trauma.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong—endorsed by the VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guidelines, APA, and WHO as a frontline PTSD treatment.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Decades of randomized controlled trials demonstrate CPT’s efficacy in reducing PTSD and associated symptoms across populations.

sections.text: CPT works by helping individuals recognize and challenge distorted trauma-related thoughts, known as 'stuck points.' Through cognitive restructuring and written trauma narratives, clients learn to reframe their interpretations of the traumatic event(s), reducing maladaptive beliefs around blame, trust, safety, and control. This cognitive shift decreases PTSD symptoms and fosters adaptive coping strategies.

sections.preparation: Assessment of trauma history, PTSD symptom severity, and readiness for trauma-focused work.
procedure: Psychoeducation about PTSD and cognitive theory.
Identification of maladaptive trauma-related beliefs ('stuck points').
Written trauma narratives to facilitate cognitive processing.
Cognitive restructuring exercises targeting distorted thinking.
Application of new beliefs to daily life situations.
sections.duration: 12 structured sessions (can be extended if clinically necessary).

sections.pre_session: Review of homework and symptom check-in.
sections.treatment_phase: Introduction of cognitive skills, identification of stuck points, processing of trauma-related thoughts.
sections.post_session: Assignment of practice exercises and monitoring of symptom changes.

immediate: Increased awareness of maladaptive trauma-related beliefs

common: Temporary increase in distress when confronting trauma memories
rare: Severe emotional flooding leading to dropout

ideal_candidates: Individuals with PTSD willing to directly engage with trauma memories
Military veterans and survivors of assault/abuse
Patients seeking a structured, time-limited therapy
screening_required: Evaluation for dissociation, suicidality, and substance use

practitioner: Licensed psychologist, psychiatrist, or clinical social worker trained in CPT

studies: Resick PA, Monson CM, Chard KM. (2017). Cognitive Processing Therapy for PTSD: A Comprehensive Manual.
Monson CM et al. (2006). Cognitive Processing Therapy for Veterans with Military-Related PTSD.
Watts BV et al. (2013). Meta-analysis of the efficacy of treatments for PTSD.
sections.limitations: Not always effective for complex trauma with severe dissociation; dropout rates can be higher in highly symptomatic populations.

sections.cost_effectiveness: Cost-effective given long-term remission and reduced healthcare utilization in trauma survivors

sections.veterans: Strong evidence base for military-related PTSD.
sections.sexual-assault-survivors: CPT was originally developed for this population with excellent efficacy.
sections.adolescents: Adapted versions exist for teens exposed to trauma.

items: CPT is one of the most strongly supported therapies for PTSD alongside Prolonged Exposure (PE) and EMDR.
Manualized, making it highly replicable and trainable.
Can be delivered individually or in group formats.
